column4: So, since I now have Vista and ubuntu to different HDDs, is there a simplish way to make it let me chooce which to boot to?
Ok, I'll try that, thanks
You get no Grub menu at bootup?
I have tried that same process and I had Grub menu at boot up but Windows was not in the options. You may very probably need to add it to your grub menu
others have had that problem. Are you able to boot from LiveCD?
not with Vista HDD installed. I removed Vista HDD though, and Ubuntu installed fine on the other HDD
this may help -->http://apcmag.com/how_to_dualboot_vista_with_linux_vista_installed_first.htm
Sorry, but that's only dealing with a single HDD
installed it on the second HDD, unable to boot to Ubuntu with Vista HDD plugged in though
We will have to look at what /boot/grub/menu.lst has and see what to edit

I don't think it's a problem with the menus to begin with. It's just that ubuntu simply won't work with Vista HDD plugged in. I can chooce which one to boot to by setting HDD priority from BIOS. Vista loads fine if I pick Vista HDD as first in boot order, but if I put Ubuntu first it tries to load but crashes if Vista HDD is installed....phew
I think Grub just lost track of where to boot your OS from. Choosing Vista from the menu works ok?
there's no menu, it goes to ubuntu automatically if I set ubuntu HDD first in BIOS boot priority, and to Vista automatically if I choose Vista first
well, that us odd
yeah. Both OSes load fine if I remove the other, Vista works with both plugged in, but ubuntu fails if I have Vista plugged
read up with me -->https://answers.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+question/31896
well that was no help
have you got too much already set up in those OSes? Coz the quickest (probably the easiest) path for you now is a reinstall the *usual* and commonly known way :)
but I can't do that, since I can't even boot the Live CD and install Ubuntu with Vista HDD installed. Only way to install ubuntu is to remove Vista HDD while installing ubuntu :(
you will want to use LiveCD of Gparted or repartitioning tools to cleanslate your drives
Yeah I guess, but I'm not sure I want to go that far. If I can't install Ubuntu on the other HDD without affecting vista, I'll just format the Ubuntu HDD as NTFS and use the extra space in Vista
i guess you can do that.. good luck!
